summary: Do you think Sandra had a good interview? She basically said eve snaps out of her delusion which is her relationship with v and...
question: Do you think Sandra had a good interview? She basically said eve snaps out of her delusion which is her relationship with v and she’s going to try and work on her marriage with Niko!
answer:
So the first thing that sticks out to me in that interview is that Sandra frequently emphasizes that they haven’t actually figured out most of the season 3 plot. So I think we need to take everything she says in this interview with a grain of salt, because even though Sandra does have some creative control, she’s not the only one, and she could very well change her mind about the way she wants things to go through discussions with Suzanne, Sally, Jodie, etc.

That said, I don’t think her “snapping out of the delusion” was referring to her having a relationship with Villanelle so much as this particular type of relationship she’s had with her over the course of the second half of the season. Here’s the quote:

It’s against Eve’s nature to really be like Villanelle, to go off on some fantasy. That’s the brutal lesson; Eve kind of wakes up from this thing. It’s like “Oh, this whole time I was really just kind of deluding myself.”

Eve has essentially been trying to have it all–her job, her relationship with Niko, her control over Villanelle as a pawn in her plan to take down Aaron, and her role as the object of Villanelle’s affections. And we see her act in increasingly heartless ways in order to keep all of these balls in the air. But as Sandra emphasizes, Eve can’t be really like Villanelle, in that she can’t keep hurting the people around her without eventually feeling remorse. I think that’s the delusion that she is waking up from here. It would be completely out of character for Eve to go from “trouble’s not interested in me” (S1E1) to leaving behind everything she’s ever known and running away with Villanelle to Alaska in the course of 16 episodes. But for a moment she allows herself to consider doing that, and then seeing how Villanelle has manipulated her reminds her who Villanelle really is and the rational side of her brain kicks in. So I don’t believe the delusion here that she refers to is her attraction to Villanelle in general, but more the way she’s been deluding herself about her own behavior and choices. And I think it makes perfect sense given the dynamic of their relationship for Eve to be the one that’s like, hang on, we need to pump the brakes here.

In regards to her relationship with Niko, here’s what Sandra says:

What I like to think about in terms of the Niko and Eve relationship is like that of a marriage. How far can you go and still come back? It’s like someone brings chaos into the house, you stop communicating well. Someone is now thinking that they can find stability outside of the marriage. You don’t really have to go that far to be able to wonder: How can you figure this out in terms of a marriage? That’s what I’m so interested in in the relationship between Eve and Niko. How can you continue being a whole person and remain in partnership?

To be honest, this answer is much more rambling and vague than her other answers. It’s like she’s saying things without actually saying anything. What that says to me is: Sandra has not spent much time thinking about the relationship between Eve and Niko, and so she’s unprepared to answer this question. Which suggests strongly to me that their relationship isn’t going to feature heavily in the next season. I do think there will be some interaction between Eve and Niko–she will probably find out what Villanelle did to Gemma and feel some type of way about it but I don’t think there is any way that the two of them will be able to get back together after what’s happened. The last line, “How can you continue being a whole person and remain in partnership?” is I think referring to Niko–how can Niko be a “whole person” in a partnership with Eve when this other figure, Villanelle, has come into their partnership and has basically eclipsed him? And I think the answer that the show already gave and will continue to give is: he can’t.

In a way though Villanelle may be the more neurodivergent of the two of them, Eve’s psyche is a lot more complicated. Because this relationship is clearly toxic, and though that doesn’t really bother Villanelle, it does bother Eve. But it still doesn’t bother her enough to walk away completely (at least until the very last scene of S2). I think Sandra is trying really, really hard to make Eve’s development feel realistic, which might involve her panicking and taking steps back from the relationship when things get too intense. I think if/when Eve finally does end up with Villanelle, we need to have a sense that the circumstances of her life and of the relationship make it completely inevitable, and I don’t think we’re there yet. I don’t, however, think there’s any way the show will remove focus from the relationship between the two of them, because that’s kind of the entire premise.

So basically, the short answer is: I liked Sandra’s interview. The things she said made sense to me. I think she has a good grasp of her character (and I think Jodie does too), so as long as the two of them are involved I feel confident about the way the next season will unfold.

title: Season Finale
body:
Ok i just rewatched the season finale and maybe an unpopular opinion? i don’t know, the fandom seems super chaotic right now…

First, i enjoyed season 2. In general i think it’s good and has a very tense build up, a couple of episodes by themselves are GREAT, 2x04 and 2x07 are up there with some of the best in season 1, and maybe 2x08 alone could be one of the best, but the thing is, it’s just a reset button. I felt this the second time watching and it was more pronounced after watching that cut scene (the cowboy Villanelle one).  I don’t know whose idea was to release that scene but it almost  ruined the whole season for me, here they showed us that Villanelle is kind of ready to just keep falling for women with amazing hair (yes, you can say that’s not true,that she will never get over Eve. but, you know -SHOW, DON’T TELL- and waht they showed was that). 

What troubles me is that if this is true then there was not character arc AT ALL, and without it, then what’s the point of telling a story?

Cosidering that cut scene as canon, all that obsession wasn’t as special as we all tought and Eve is not as dark (or special) as they made us believe.  I am not asking for Villanelle to be all romantic and shit (tough she is….sometimes, in her own way) , but the point of watching these two circle each other, the special thing about it, is how much they change the closer they get, in my opinion this was well done along the season but went to the toillet at the end…

Like i said, i liked the season, it has serious continuity problems and lots of plot holes, but as a character study was good…till the end?

I hope season 3 brings back this sense of uniqueness to their relationship, i still want them to be messy and dangerous and paranoid, but i want the excitement of  watching a once in a lifetime event.

@what-you-dont-surrender @thelma2017dirjoachimtrier 

(i am taggin you guys beacuse i love your analisys and want to know your take at this)

(Also, sorry, english it is not my first language)

Cosidering that cut scene as canon, all that obsession wasn’t as special as we all tought and Eve is not as dark (or special) as they made us believe.  I am not asking for Villanelle to be all romantic and shit (tough she is….sometimes, in her own way) , but the point of watching these two circle each other, the special thing about it, is how much they change the closer they get, in my opinion this was well done along the season but went to the toillet at the end…

Like i said, i liked the season, it has serious continuity problems and lots of plot holes, but as a character study was good…till the end?

I hope season 3 brings back this sense of uniqueness to their relationship, i still want them to be messy and dangerous and paranoid, but i want the excitement of  watching a once in a lifetime event.

@what-you-dont-surrender @thelma2017dirjoachimtrier 

(i am taggin you guys beacuse i love your analisys and want to know your take at this)

(Also, sorry, english it is not my first language)

summary: “The idea of trying to let go of the end result is something I really try to focus on. When I have fear, I have one mantra and...
body:
“The idea of trying to let go of the end result is something I really try to focus on. When I have fear, I have one mantra and one feeling that I try to focus on, which is, ‘I know how to be present.’ It’s a reminder that you already know to do it and you can do it.” - Sandra Oh

“Some days your emotion could be just right at the surface and you surprise yourself, and I’m like, ‘Whoa, where did that come from?’ I find it quite cathartic in the sense that I get to release so much through her throughout the day.” - Jodie Comer

Emmys 2019: Leading Women

summary: I could go on for hours and hours about the dynamic between Eve and Villanelle but simply put, what makes this ship so alluring...
body: I could go on for hours and hours about the dynamic between Eve and Villanelle but simply put, what makes this ship so alluring is that they are impossible while also being inevitable. They’re enough alike in the right ways to connect on such a deep level, but they’re also so different and each crave what the other has while never fully being able to have it. What draws them to each other is what also creates the rift. It’s the ultimate forbidden love story, not just because of outside circumstances, but because of their own fucking psychology that simultaneously makes them need to embrace and destroy each other.

They’re enough alike in the right ways to connect on such a deep level, but they’re also so different and each crave what the other has while never fully being able to have it. What draws them to each other is what also creates the rift. It’s the ultimate forbidden love story, not just because of outside circumstances, but because of their own fucking psychology that simultaneously makes them need to embrace and destroy each other.

They’re enough alike in the right ways to connect on such a deep level, but they’re also so different and each crave what the other has while never fully being able to have it. What draws them to each other is what also creates the rift. It’s the ultimate forbidden love story, not just because of outside circumstances, but because of their own fucking psychology that simultaneously makes them need to embrace and destroy each other.

summary: REVIEW: Killing Eve, S2 Ep8 - You're Mine
title: REVIEW: Killing Eve, S2 Ep8 - You're Mine
body:
REVIEW: Killing Eve, S2 Ep8 – You’re Mine

The Killing Eve finale leaves both leads lost and betrayed, by others and by each other, after a picturesque stroll around Rome. In some ways, the mission did go as planned, at least by Carolyn’s standards. And the end of the season saw both Villanelle and Eve working directly with each other and realizing that being together is not what either of them expected.

It turns out that Aaron Peele…

View On WordPress

summary: Recently rewatched S1 of Killing Eve which reminded me how much I love it + I’m looking forward to S2. (The only thing I didn’t...
body:
Recently rewatched S1 of Killing Eve which reminded me how much I love it + I’m looking forward to S2. (The only thing I didn’t like is that they killed off Bill, I really wish they hadn’t as I loved his character + his friendship w/Eve).

Also watched Iron Sky: The Coming Race which is every bit as bonkers + nonsensical as you would expect from a film that features Adolf Hitler riding a dinosaur around a moonbase (I mean that in a good + a bad way!)
